awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Design, Create, and Innovate 3-Dimensional User Interfaces to Improve  Human Sensory and Motor Performance in Virtual Environments (HUMANS MOVE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The HUMANS MOVE project at the University of Wyoming is a 10-week interdisciplinary summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program to design, create, and innovate 3-Dimensional User Interfaces (3D UIs) to improve human sensory and motor performances in Virtual Environments. Students will be recruited from diverse backgrounds, disciplines, and underrepresented populations, especially in rural areas or where opportunities in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) are limited. The HUMANS MOVE REU Site will host ten students and provide positive research experiences, training, mentorship, state-of-the-art facilities and equipment, experiential learning activities, tailored resources, and networking connections that will continue to foster students' growth and success in research, graduate studies, and career development. The broader impact of this REU Site is to broaden the participation of underrepresented populations in computing, increase enrollment and retention of those students in graduate studies, and further enhance innovation through increased diverse thinking and creativity.

The selected projects for the HUMANS MOVE REU Site focus on conducting state-of-the-art computing research in 3-Dimensional User Interfaces for Immersive Environments, such as Virtual/Augmented/Mixed Reality or Immersive Visualizations. The application areas focus on improving human sensory and motor performance in spatial environments, motor rehabilitation, collaboration and cooperation, and other 3D spatial tasks. The REU site students will collaborate with talented multidisciplinary teams of faculty, students, and staff in areas of computer science, electrical and computer engineering, kinesiology, visualization, art, and design to foster creativity and innovation. Student researchers will evaluate human physical, cognitive, or sensory challenges to inform the design and development of new interaction techniques, input devices, or methods of training, rehabilitation, or augmentation. In addition to collaborating with the research team, students will work together with users or patients to evaluate their proposed solutions. The HUMANS MOVE REU Site will engage students in impactful research projects that will advance technical achievements in 3D User Interfaces, Virtual/Augmented/Mixed Reality applications, training, or rehabilitation as well as broader outcomes to improve 3D tasks, scientific workflow, human health, or the community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF REU Site: Design, Create, and Innovate 3-Dimensional User Interfaces to Improve Human Sensory and Motor Performance in Virtual Environments (HUMANS MOVE) is an established 10-week undergraduate research experience in the College of Engineering and Applied Science at the University of Wyoming that focuses research activities on creating, designing, and innovating novel 3D User Interfaces, devices, and interaction techniques. The Intellectual Merit of this three year NSF REU Site was focused on conducting state-of-the-art research in 3-Dimensional User Interfaces (3D UI) for Immersive Environments, such as virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR) and immersive visualizations. REU students worked with and were mentored by multidisciplinary teams of faculty, students, and staff in areas of computer science, electrical and computer engineering, kinesiology, visualization, art, and design. REU students completed research projects that had the potential to improve 3D tasks, scientific workflow, health, and community improvement. 

HUMANS MOVE engaged undergraduate students in scholarly activity by coordinating collaboration on innovative research with talented multidisciplinary teams using state-of-the-art facilities and equipment. Engaging students through identifying research questions that resonate with them, yet using design strategies and techniques to converge project scopes early, we are able to engage students in the research process quickly and effectively. Students have expressed that the hands-on process by which they are learning and immersed in the research community has had a positive impact and individualized growth in their work ethic, skills, knowledge, career, and their life. As a result, REU participants were passionate about their research topics. Through close mentorship, REU student participants have completed novel work, specific research problems have been solved and/or expanded, students have become interested in research, and students' research skills have expanded. HUMANS MOVE student participants have been successful at completing novel research projects and publishing their work in peer reviewed conferences and journals. Through the process students develop as ethical leaders and are skilled in research methodology skills related to the intellectual focus of the program through CITI Training and other extensive training and mentorship provided in the program. 

The HUMANS MOVE program provided opportunities for training, mentorship, and resources for students from underrepresented populations in computing by immersing students in research community, experiential learning activities, and networking connections that continue to foster students' growth and success in research and career development. Students upon completion of the program demonstrated significant increased of knowledge in VR/AR, related research methodologies, procedures when working with human subjects, awareness of graduate school and computing careers, professional development skills in communicating, project planning, design, and increased confidence and belonging.

We believe a diverse team is a key to creativity and successful innovation. Creating, designing, and innovating novel 3D User Interfaces, devices, and interaction techniques benefits from a wide variety of skills and backgrounds from computing and non-computing fields. Our multidisciplinary research area lends itself to students who can participate from a variety of backgrounds and the tools we use can be used by students without extensive computer science experience. The broader impact of HUMANS MOVE was to broaden the participation of underrepresented populations in computing, increase enrollment and retention of those students in graduate studies, and further enhance innovation through increased diverse thinking and creativity. Contributing to this broader impact, HUMANS MOVE recruited students consistently over 75% from other institutions, over 50% from underrepresented groups in computing, over 50% from institutions that have no to limited research opportunities for undergraduate students and at least 20% from community colleges. 

HUMANS MOVE engaged a diverse set of students from populations that are limited in computing and foster developmental growth by providing a multidisciplinary experience, training in both research and technical computing skills, and providing tailored mentorship support and resources. HUMANS MOVE increased students' potential from underrepresented populations in computing to pursue graduate studies by fostering positive experiences, time with graduate student mentors, and providing knowledge, and resources on graduate school. Evidence of the program has resulted in half of students currently attending, applying for, or considering graduate studies, yet through education and mentorship of these alternative pathways, students have more tools to be able to make the right decisions for their careers even if that is not graduate school. HUMANS MOVE raised awareness of, importance, and impacts of emerging fields in computing by providing an informative, collaborative, and meaningful experience with impactful projects. Students learn how to conduct productive peer critique sessions and receive feedback from faculty and students in a collaborative team. 

In summary, over 3 years NSF REU Site: HUMANS MOVE has successfully recruited 30 students to participate in exciting novel research opportunities resulting in increased awareness and knowledge, published research work with impacts related to the intellectual merit, refined professional skills, career path development, and positive impacts on the number of students from underrepresented groups in computing fields considering or pursuing graduate school and research focused careers.
